scene.title: SCENE I. Padua. Before LUCENTIO'S house.

scene-body.stagedir: GREMIO discovered. Enter behind BIONDELLO, LUCENTIO, and BIANCA

speech.speaker: BIONDELLO
speech.line: Softly and swiftly, sir; for the priest is ready.

speech.speaker: LUCENTIO
speech.line: I fly, Biondello: but they may chance to need thee
at home; therefore leave us.

speech.speaker: BIONDELLO
speech.line: Nay, faith, I'll see the church o' your back; and
then come back to my master's as soon as I can.

speech.speaker: GREMIO
speech.line: I marvel Cambio comes not all this while.

scene-body.stagedir: Enter PETRUCHIO, KATHARINA, VINCENTIO, GRUMIO, with Attendants

speech.speaker: PETRUCHIO
speech.line: Sir, here's the door, this is Lucentio's house:
My father's bears more toward the market-place;
Thither must I, and here I leave you, sir.

speech.speaker: VINCENTIO
speech.line: You shall not choose but drink before you go:
I think I shall command your welcome here,
And, by all likelihood, some cheer is toward.

speech.speaker: GREMIO
speech.line: They're busy within; you were best knock louder.

scene-body.stagedir: Pedant looks out of the window

speech.speaker: Pedant
speech.line: What's he that knocks as he would beat down the gate?

speech.speaker: VINCENTIO
speech.line: Is Signior Lucentio within, sir?

speech.speaker: Pedant
speech.line: He's within, sir, but not to be spoken withal.

speech.speaker: VINCENTIO
speech.line: What if a man bring him a hundred pound or two, to
make merry withal?

speech.speaker: Pedant
speech.line: Keep your hundred pounds to yourself: he shall
need none, so long as I live.

speech.speaker: PETRUCHIO
speech.line: Nay, I told you your son was well beloved in Padua.
Do you hear, sir? To leave frivolous circumstances,
I pray you, tell Signior Lucentio that his father is
come from Pisa, and is here at the door to speak with him.

speech.speaker: Pedant
speech.line: Thou liest: his father is come from Padua and here
looking out at the window.

speech.speaker: VINCENTIO
speech.line: Art thou his father?

speech.speaker: Pedant
speech.line: Ay, sir; so his mother says, if I may believe her.

speech.speaker: PETRUCHIO
speech.line: To VINCENTIO Why, how now, gentleman! why, this
is flat knavery, to take upon you another man's name.

speech.speaker: Pedant
speech.line: Lay hands on the villain: I believe a' means to
cozen somebody in this city under my countenance.

speech.speaker: BIONDELLO
speech.line: I have seen them in the church together: God send
'em good shipping! But who is here? mine old
master Vincentio! now we are undone and brought to nothing.

speech.speaker: VINCENTIO
speech.line: Come hither, crack-hemp.

speech.speaker: BIONDELLO
speech.line: Hope I may choose, sir.

speech.speaker: VINCENTIO
speech.line: Come hither, you rogue. What, have you forgot me?

speech.speaker: BIONDELLO
speech.line: Forgot you! no, sir: I could not forget you, for I
never saw you before in all my life.

speech.speaker: VINCENTIO
speech.line: What, you notorious villain, didst thou never see
thy master's father, Vincentio?

speech.speaker: BIONDELLO
speech.line: What, my old worshipful old master? yes, marry, sir:
see where he looks out of the window.

speech.speaker: VINCENTIO
speech.line: Is't so, indeed.

speech.speaker: BIONDELLO
speech.line: Help, help, help! here's a madman will murder me.

speech.speaker: Pedant
speech.line: Help, son! help, Signior Baptista!

speech.speaker: PETRUCHIO
speech.line: Prithee, Kate, let's stand aside and see the end of
this controversy.

scene-body.stagedir: Re-enter Pedant below; TRANIO, BAPTISTA, and Servants

speech.speaker: TRANIO
speech.line: Sir, what are you that offer to beat my servant?

speech.speaker: VINCENTIO
speech.line: What am I, sir! nay, what are you, sir? O immortal
gods! O fine villain! A silken doublet! a velvet
hose! a scarlet cloak! and a copatain hat! O, I
am undone! I am undone! while I play the good
husband at home, my son and my servant spend all at
the university.

speech.speaker: TRANIO
speech.line: How now! what's the matter?

speech.speaker: BAPTISTA
speech.line: What, is the man lunatic?

speech.speaker: TRANIO
speech.line: Sir, you seem a sober ancient gentleman by your
habit, but your words show you a madman. Why, sir,
what 'cerns it you if I wear pearl and gold? I
thank my good father, I am able to maintain it.

speech.speaker: VINCENTIO
speech.line: Thy father! O villain! he is a sailmaker in Bergamo.

speech.speaker: BAPTISTA
speech.line: You mistake, sir, you mistake, sir. Pray, what do
you think is his name?

speech.speaker: VINCENTIO
speech.line: His name! as if I knew not his name: I have brought
him up ever since he was three years old, and his
name is Tranio.

speech.speaker: Pedant
speech.line: Away, away, mad ass! his name is Lucentio and he is
mine only son, and heir to the lands of me, Signior Vincentio.

speech.speaker: VINCENTIO
speech.line: Lucentio! O, he hath murdered his master! Lay hold
on him, I charge you, in the duke's name. O, my
son, my son! Tell me, thou villain, where is my son Lucentio?

speech.speaker: TRANIO
speech.line: Call forth an officer.
Carry this mad knave to the gaol. Father Baptista,
I charge you see that he be forthcoming.

speech.speaker: VINCENTIO
speech.line: Carry me to the gaol!

speech.speaker: GREMIO
speech.line: Stay, officer: he shall not go to prison.

speech.speaker: BAPTISTA
speech.line: Talk not, Signior Gremio: I say he shall go to prison.

speech.speaker: GREMIO
speech.line: Take heed, Signior Baptista, lest you be
cony-catched in this business: I dare swear this
is the right Vincentio.

speech.speaker: Pedant
speech.line: Swear, if thou darest.

speech.speaker: GREMIO
speech.line: Nay, I dare not swear it.

speech.speaker: TRANIO
speech.line: Then thou wert best say that I am not Lucentio.

speech.speaker: GREMIO
speech.line: Yes, I know thee to be Signior Lucentio.

speech.speaker: BAPTISTA
speech.line: Away with the dotard! to the gaol with him!

speech.speaker: VINCENTIO
speech.line: Thus strangers may be hailed and abused: O
monstrous villain!

scene-body.stagedir: Re-enter BIONDELLO, with LUCENTIO and BIANCA

speech.speaker: BIONDELLO
speech.line: O! we are spoiled and--yonder he is: deny him,
forswear him, or else we are all undone.

speech.speaker: LUCENTIO
speech.line: Kneeling Pardon, sweet father.

speech.speaker: VINCENTIO
speech.line: Lives my sweet son?

scene-body.stagedir: Exeunt BIONDELLO, TRANIO, and Pedant, as fast as may be

speech.speaker: BIANCA
speech.line: Pardon, dear father.

speech.speaker: BAPTISTA
speech.line: How hast thou offended?
Where is Lucentio?

speech.speaker: LUCENTIO
speech.line: Here's Lucentio,
Right son to the right Vincentio;
That have by marriage made thy daughter mine,
While counterfeit supposes bleared thine eyne.

speech.speaker: GREMIO
speech.line: Here's packing, with a witness to deceive us all!

speech.speaker: VINCENTIO
speech.line: Where is that damned villain Tranio,
That faced and braved me in this matter so?

speech.speaker: BAPTISTA
speech.line: Why, tell me, is not this my Cambio?

speech.speaker: BIANCA
speech.line: Cambio is changed into Lucentio.

speech.speaker: LUCENTIO
speech.line: Love wrought these miracles. Bianca's love
Made me exchange my state with Tranio,
While he did bear my countenance in the town;
And happily I have arrived at the last
Unto the wished haven of my bliss.
What Tranio did, myself enforced him to;
Then pardon him, sweet father, for my sake.

speech.speaker: VINCENTIO
speech.line: I'll slit the villain's nose, that would have sent
me to the gaol.

speech.speaker: BAPTISTA
speech.line: But do you hear, sir? have you married my daughter
without asking my good will?

speech.speaker: VINCENTIO
speech.line: Fear not, Baptista; we will content you, go to: but
I will in, to be revenged for this villany.

speech.speaker: BAPTISTA
speech.line: And I, to sound the depth of this knavery.

speech.speaker: LUCENTIO
speech.line: Look not pale, Bianca; thy father will not frown.

speech.speaker: GREMIO
speech.line: My cake is dough; but I'll in among the rest,
Out of hope of all, but my share of the feast.

speech.speaker: KATHARINA
speech.line: Husband, let's follow, to see the end of this ado.

speech.speaker: PETRUCHIO
speech.line: First kiss me, Kate, and we will.

speech.speaker: KATHARINA
speech.line: What, in the midst of the street?

speech.speaker: PETRUCHIO
speech.line: What, art thou ashamed of me?

speech.speaker: KATHARINA
speech.line: No, sir, God forbid; but ashamed to kiss.

speech.speaker: PETRUCHIO
speech.line: Why, then let's home again. Come, sirrah, let's away.

speech.speaker: KATHARINA
speech.line: Nay, I will give thee a kiss: now pray thee, love, stay.

speech.speaker: PETRUCHIO
speech.line: Is not this well? Come, my sweet Kate:
Better once than never, for never too late.

scene-body.stagedir: Enter BAPTISTA, VINCENTIO, GREMIO, the Pedant, LUCENTIO, BIANCA, PETRUCHIO, KATHARINA, HORTENSIO, and Widow, TRANIO, BIONDELLO, and GRUMIO the Serving-men with Tranio bringing in a banquet

speech.speaker: LUCENTIO
speech.line: At last, though long, our jarring notes agree:
And time it is, when raging war is done,
To smile at scapes and perils overblown.
My fair Bianca, bid my father welcome,
While I with self-same kindness welcome thine.
Brother Petruchio, sister Katharina,
And thou, Hortensio, with thy loving widow,
Feast with the best, and welcome to my house:
My banquet is to close our stomachs up,
After our great good cheer. Pray you, sit down;
For now we sit to chat as well as eat.

speech.speaker: PETRUCHIO
speech.line: Nothing but sit and sit, and eat and eat!

speech.speaker: BAPTISTA
speech.line: Padua affords this kindness, son Petruchio.

speech.speaker: PETRUCHIO
speech.line: Padua affords nothing but what is kind.

speech.speaker: HORTENSIO
speech.line: For both our sakes, I would that word were true.

speech.speaker: PETRUCHIO
speech.line: Now, for my life, Hortensio fears his widow.

speech.speaker: Widow
speech.line: Then never trust me, if I be afeard.

speech.speaker: PETRUCHIO
speech.line: You are very sensible, and yet you miss my sense:
I mean, Hortensio is afeard of you.

speech.speaker: Widow
speech.line: He that is giddy thinks the world turns round.

speech.speaker: PETRUCHIO
speech.line: Roundly replied.

speech.speaker: KATHARINA
speech.line: Mistress, how mean you that?

speech.speaker: Widow
speech.line: Thus I conceive by him.

speech.speaker: PETRUCHIO
speech.line: Conceives by me! How likes Hortensio that?

speech.speaker: HORTENSIO
speech.line: My widow says, thus she conceives her tale.

speech.speaker: PETRUCHIO
speech.line: Very well mended. Kiss him for that, good widow.

speech.speaker: KATHARINA
speech.line: 'He that is giddy thinks the world turns round:'
I pray you, tell me what you meant by that.

speech.speaker: Widow
speech.line: Your husband, being troubled with a shrew,
Measures my husband's sorrow by his woe:
And now you know my meaning,

speech.speaker: KATHARINA
speech.line: A very mean meaning.

speech.speaker: Widow
speech.line: Right, I mean you.

speech.speaker: KATHARINA
speech.line: And I am mean indeed, respecting you.

speech.speaker: PETRUCHIO
speech.line: To her, Kate!

speech.speaker: HORTENSIO
speech.line: To her, widow!

speech.speaker: PETRUCHIO
speech.line: A hundred marks, my Kate does put her down.

speech.speaker: HORTENSIO
speech.line: That's my office.

speech.speaker: PETRUCHIO
speech.line: Spoke like an officer; ha' to thee, lad!

speech.speaker: BAPTISTA
speech.line: How likes Gremio these quick-witted folks?

speech.speaker: GREMIO
speech.line: Believe me, sir, they butt together well.

speech.speaker: BIANCA
speech.line: Head, and butt! an hasty-witted body
Would say your head and butt were head and horn.

speech.speaker: VINCENTIO
speech.line: Ay, mistress bride, hath that awaken'd you?

speech.speaker: BIANCA
speech.line: Ay, but not frighted me; therefore I'll sleep again.

speech.speaker: PETRUCHIO
speech.line: Nay, that you shall not: since you have begun,
Have at you for a bitter jest or two!

speech.speaker: BIANCA
speech.line: Am I your bird? I mean to shift my bush;
And then pursue me as you draw your bow.
You are welcome all.

speech.speaker: PETRUCHIO
speech.line: She hath prevented me. Here, Signior Tranio.
This bird you aim'd at, though you hit her not;
Therefore a health to all that shot and miss'd.

speech.speaker: TRANIO
speech.line: O, sir, Lucentio slipp'd me like his greyhound,
Which runs himself and catches for his master.

speech.speaker: PETRUCHIO
speech.line: A good swift simile, but something currish.

speech.speaker: TRANIO
speech.line: 'Tis well, sir, that you hunted for yourself:
'Tis thought your deer does hold you at a bay.

speech.speaker: BAPTISTA
speech.line: O ho, Petruchio! Tranio hits you now.

speech.speaker: LUCENTIO
speech.line: I thank thee for that gird, good Tranio.

speech.speaker: HORTENSIO
speech.line: Confess, confess, hath he not hit you here?

speech.speaker: PETRUCHIO
speech.line: A' has a little gall'd me, I confess;
And, as the jest did glance away from me,
'Tis ten to one it maim'd you two outright.

speech.speaker: BAPTISTA
speech.line: Now, in good sadness, son Petruchio,
I think thou hast the veriest shrew of all.

speech.speaker: PETRUCHIO
speech.line: Well, I say no: and therefore for assurance
Let's each one send unto his wife;
And he whose wife is most obedient
To come at first when he doth send for her,
Shall win the wager which we will propose.

speech.speaker: HORTENSIO
speech.line: Content. What is the wager?

speech.speaker: LUCENTIO
speech.line: Twenty crowns.

speech.speaker: PETRUCHIO
speech.line: Twenty crowns!
I'll venture so much of my hawk or hound,
But twenty times so much upon my wife.

speech.speaker: LUCENTIO
speech.line: A hundred then.

speech.speaker: HORTENSIO
speech.line: Content.

speech.speaker: PETRUCHIO
speech.line: A match! 'tis done.

speech.speaker: HORTENSIO
speech.line: Who shall begin?

speech.speaker: LUCENTIO
speech.line: That will I.
Go, Biondello, bid your mistress come to me.

speech.speaker: BIONDELLO
speech.line: I go.

speech.speaker: BAPTISTA
speech.line: Son, I'll be your half, Bianca comes.

speech.speaker: LUCENTIO
speech.line: I'll have no halves; I'll bear it all myself.
How now! what news?

speech.speaker: BIONDELLO
speech.line: Sir, my mistress sends you word
That she is busy and she cannot come.

speech.speaker: PETRUCHIO
speech.line: How! she is busy and she cannot come!
Is that an answer?

speech.speaker: GREMIO
speech.line: Ay, and a kind one too:
Pray God, sir, your wife send you not a worse.

speech.speaker: PETRUCHIO
speech.line: I hope better.

speech.speaker: HORTENSIO
speech.line: Sirrah Biondello, go and entreat my wife
To come to me forthwith.

speech.speaker: PETRUCHIO
speech.line: O, ho! entreat her!
Nay, then she must needs come.

speech.speaker: HORTENSIO
speech.line: I am afraid, sir,
Do what you can, yours will not be entreated.
Now, where's my wife?

speech.speaker: BIONDELLO
speech.line: She says you have some goodly jest in hand:
She will not come: she bids you come to her.

speech.speaker: PETRUCHIO
speech.line: Worse and worse; she will not come! O vile,
Intolerable, not to be endured!
Sirrah Grumio, go to your mistress;
Say, I command her to come to me.

speech.speaker: HORTENSIO
speech.line: I know her answer.

speech.speaker: PETRUCHIO
speech.line: What?

speech.speaker: HORTENSIO
speech.line: She will not.

speech.speaker: PETRUCHIO
speech.line: The fouler fortune mine, and there an end.

speech.speaker: BAPTISTA
speech.line: Now, by my holidame, here comes Katharina!

speech.speaker: KATHARINA
speech.line: What is your will, sir, that you send for me?

speech.speaker: PETRUCHIO
speech.line: Where is your sister, and Hortensio's wife?

speech.speaker: KATHARINA
speech.line: They sit conferring by the parlor fire.

speech.speaker: PETRUCHIO
speech.line: Go fetch them hither: if they deny to come.
Swinge me them soundly forth unto their husbands:
Away, I say, and bring them hither straight.

speech.speaker: LUCENTIO
speech.line: Here is a wonder, if you talk of a wonder.

speech.speaker: HORTENSIO
speech.line: And so it is: I wonder what it bodes.

speech.speaker: PETRUCHIO
speech.line: Marry, peace it bodes, and love and quiet life,
And awful rule and right supremacy;
And, to be short, what not, that's sweet and happy?

speech.speaker: BAPTISTA
speech.line: Now, fair befal thee, good Petruchio!
The wager thou hast won; and I will add
Unto their losses twenty thousand crowns;
Another dowry to another daughter,
For she is changed, as she had never been.

speech.speaker: PETRUCHIO
speech.line: Nay, I will win my wager better yet
And show more sign of her obedience,
Her new-built virtue and obedience.
See where she comes and brings your froward wives
As prisoners to her womanly persuasion.
speech.stagedir: Re-enter KATHARINA, with BIANCA and Widow
speech.line: Katharina, that cap of yours becomes you not:
Off with that bauble, throw it under-foot.

speech.speaker: Widow
speech.line: Lord, let me never have a cause to sigh,
Till I be brought to such a silly pass!

speech.speaker: BIANCA
speech.line: Fie! what a foolish duty call you this?

speech.speaker: LUCENTIO
speech.line: I would your duty were as foolish too:
The wisdom of your duty, fair Bianca,
Hath cost me an hundred crowns since supper-time.

speech.speaker: BIANCA
speech.line: The more fool you, for laying on my duty.

speech.speaker: PETRUCHIO
speech.line: Katharina, I charge thee, tell these headstrong women
What duty they do owe their lords and husbands.

speech.speaker: Widow
speech.line: Come, come, you're mocking: we will have no telling.

speech.speaker: PETRUCHIO
speech.line: Come on, I say; and first begin with her.

speech.speaker: Widow
speech.line: She shall not.

speech.speaker: PETRUCHIO
speech.line: I say she shall: and first begin with her.

speech.speaker: KATHARINA
speech.line: Fie, fie! unknit that threatening unkind brow,
And dart not scornful glances from those eyes,
To wound thy lord, thy king, thy governor:
It blots thy beauty as frosts do bite the meads,
Confounds thy fame as whirlwinds shake fair buds,
And in no sense is meet or amiable.
A woman moved is like a fountain troubled,
Muddy, ill-seeming, thick, bereft of beauty;
And while it is so, none so dry or thirsty
Will deign to sip or touch one drop of it.
Thy husband is thy lord, thy life, thy keeper,
Thy head, thy sovereign; one that cares for thee,
And for thy maintenance commits his body
To painful labour both by sea and land,
To watch the night in storms, the day in cold,
Whilst thou liest warm at home, secure and safe;
And craves no other tribute at thy hands
But love, fair looks and true obedience;
Too little payment for so great a debt.
Such duty as the subject owes the prince
Even such a woman oweth to her husband;
And when she is froward, peevish, sullen, sour,
And not obedient to his honest will,
What is she but a foul contending rebel
And graceless traitor to her loving lord?
I am ashamed that women are so simple
To offer war where they should kneel for peace;
Or seek for rule, supremacy and sway,
When they are bound to serve, love and obey.
Why are our bodies soft and weak and smooth,
Unapt to toil and trouble in the world,
But that our soft conditions and our hearts
Should well agree with our external parts?
Come, come, you froward and unable worms!
My mind hath been as big as one of yours,
My heart as great, my reason haply more,
To bandy word for word and frown for frown;
But now I see our lances are but straws,
Our strength as weak, our weakness past compare,
That seeming to be most which we indeed least are.
Then vail your stomachs, for it is no boot,
And place your hands below your husband's foot:
In token of which duty, if he please,
My hand is ready; may it do him ease.

speech.speaker: PETRUCHIO
speech.line: Why, there's a wench! Come on, and kiss me, Kate.

speech.speaker: LUCENTIO
speech.line: Well, go thy ways, old lad; for thou shalt ha't.

speech.speaker: VINCENTIO
speech.line: 'Tis a good hearing when children are toward.

speech.speaker: LUCENTIO
speech.line: But a harsh hearing when women are froward.

speech.speaker: PETRUCHIO
speech.line: Come, Kate, we'll to bed.
We three are married, but you two are sped.
'Twas I won the wager, though you hit the white;
And, being a winner, God give you good night!

speech.speaker: HORTENSIO
speech.line: Now, go thy ways; thou hast tamed a curst shrew.

speech.speaker: LUCENTIO
speech.line: 'Tis a wonder, by your leave, she will be tamed so.
